headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have been, over the last few years, more successful, faster than we anticipated as far as having our suppliers help us with financing inventory and utilizing our vendor financing program. In addition, operating results have been very good. So we've gen
componenttext: We have been, over the last few years, more successful, faster than we anticipated as far as having our suppliers help us with financing inventory and utilizing our vendor financing program. In addition, operating results have been very good. So we've generated more cash than we've expected. We continue to look for opportunities to get the best return on that cash. To date, that's been repurchasing shares. And you saw that we picked up the amount of repurchases we had during this quarter, so we saw some great opportunities. We'll continue to prudently execute that to the extent that we have cash on the balance sheet. We're not going to go out and raise debt to have more cash get on the balance sheet and have a negative carry. So when we have opportunities to invest or if we don't have cash on hand, we will look at that point to raise our -- to raise more -- some more debt.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Matthew Fassler from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Matthew Fassler from Goldman Sachs.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first and primary question relates to your comments on parts complexity. If you can just talk about how the change in profile of parts complexity is impacting the DIY business versus the pro business. How would it impact sort of the service needs in th
componenttext: My first and primary question relates to your comments on parts complexity. If you can just talk about how the change in profile of parts complexity is impacting the DIY business versus the pro business. How would it impact sort of the service needs in the DIY area as well. And then finally, what do you think that's having an impact on the ticket of the business?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it does have an impact on the ticket in the business, and I think it will have for the foreseeable future. I think that to the extent that we're talking to parts that are increasing in complexity, which is a big part of our business, absent
componenttext: Well, I think it does have an impact on the ticket in the business, and I think it will have for the foreseeable future. I think that to the extent that we're talking to parts that are increasing in complexity, which is a big part of our business, absent the things that we carry in our display floors, because the types of products that are being used that are electronic oriented, more sensors. Vehicles are in the process now going to direct injection, both diesel and gas. Ignition parts are going to 1 coil per cylinder as oppose to 1 coil for the car. And then newer vehicles have all these life safety sensors, and so forth, that add complexity. We see that driving the cost of repair incrementally up over time. It's hard to forecast what that increase will look like, but that will continue to happen. Net -- all of the things that I just mentioned tend to make us believe and make others believe that the professional business will grow a little better in the coming years than what the DIY business will, simply because this complexity is a challenge for DIY customers. Although, as I've said many times before and as cars originally started having onboard computers, sensors and so forth, I think that the DIY customer out of economic necessity is very adaptable and there's a lot of companies that are out there providing information and tools to help DIY customers be able to work on cars. They have more sensors and more electronics. And for that reason, there's many that bet that the DIY business is going to do pretty well. So that's my comment on that.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's terrific. And just following up on that, putting aside the aging vehicle fleet, obviously, and just thinking about pound for pound, is there a change in the average age of vehicle that's coming in via DIY versus pro or DIFM based on some of the evo
componenttext: That's terrific. And just following up on that, putting aside the aging vehicle fleet, obviously, and just thinking about pound for pound, is there a change in the average age of vehicle that's coming in via DIY versus pro or DIFM based on some of the evolving technology that you discussed? Are cars making their way into the DIFM channel? Or I guess staying in the DIFM channel longer, do you think, based on some of the things you just talked about?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think so. And I think that's a trend we'll continue to see. I think the later-motor vehicles, which are more complex. The 2015s are the most complex. I think that, that trend has been going on for several years and that those cars that have the highest
componenttext: I think so. And I think that's a trend we'll continue to see. I think the later-motor vehicles, which are more complex. The 2015s are the most complex. I think that, that trend has been going on for several years and that those cars that have the highest levels of complexity tend to stay in the do-it-for-me channel longer than what they had years back when DIY customers were able to work on them pretty easily as they came out of warranty.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dan Wewer from Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dan Wewer from Raymond James.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So your do-it-yourself same-store sales are growing fastest in the sector, yet if you look at O'Reilly's do-it-yourself revenues per store, it appears to be about $500,000 less compared to AutoZone. When you think about the art of the possible for O'Reill
componenttext: So your do-it-yourself same-store sales are growing fastest in the sector, yet if you look at O'Reilly's do-it-yourself revenues per store, it appears to be about $500,000 less compared to AutoZone. When you think about the art of the possible for O'Reilly's do-it-yourself revenues per location, do you think it could be in line with that competitor? And if so, what changes would you need to make? I know you've been growing your private label business. You've been expanding your store labor hours to target do-it-yourselfer, but are there any other initiatives that you need to make to achieve that kind of productivity?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Dan, as we've said for some time, we view ourselves as having competitors that do better on the DIY side than what we have in the past. And I think that some of the things that we've done over the past 3 or 4 years to put ourselves in a better posit
componenttext: Well, Dan, as we've said for some time, we view ourselves as having competitors that do better on the DIY side than what we have in the past. And I think that some of the things that we've done over the past 3 or 4 years to put ourselves in a better position to compete on a equivalent service level perspective with the best retailers in the business, I think is attributed to our growth in the DIY business and will continue to do so. The way I view this is we had this big opportunity to do more DIY business just as we have this big opportunity to do more on the do-it-for-me side. Although we, as you've stated, underperformed some of our biggest competitors on the DIY side on a per store basis. And the way I look at this is just like going up a staircase. You take it one step at a time. And we've made a lot of positive changes that I feel like are attributing to our DIY growth, and we'll continue to benefit from those changes. As we see opportunities for things that we might be able to do to grow our DIY business better without infringing on our do-it-for-me business, we'll continue to do that. I think that there's a lot of reasons that we have an opportunity here, partly based on the team members that we have that are just really good parts people. They know cars, they know parts, they know customer service. I think that our availability of product is unsurpassed in our industry, and I think that as DIY customers who maybe did business with one of our competitors previously and maybe you can come into our store lately, I think as they realize that we have this fantastic availability model, I think that just bodes well for us in the future. So I look forward to DIY business to continue to be a significant part of our growth even with the headwind of parts complexity that I was talking about earlier. And as we see things that we need to adjust to make sure we continue to take market share in that side of the business, we'll continue to do so.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Also, a question for Jeff as my follow-up. You talked about putting in more stores into the California market and filling where CSK was not located. It's been sometime since you've given us an update on how the former CSK stores are performing in terms of
componenttext: Also, a question for Jeff as my follow-up. You talked about putting in more stores into the California market and filling where CSK was not located. It's been sometime since you've given us an update on how the former CSK stores are performing in terms of revenues. As I recall, they were probably over indexing on the do-it-yourself channel and underperforming on commercial. Could you give us an update on how those stores are comparing, to say, where they were 6 or 7 years ago?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: As Greg mentioned, over all, I mean those stores, that group of stores, continues to perform solidly on both sides of the business. We knew our biggest opportunity was grow the professional side of the business, so we've worked hard on that from a -- just
componenttext: As Greg mentioned, over all, I mean those stores, that group of stores, continues to perform solidly on both sides of the business. We knew our biggest opportunity was grow the professional side of the business, so we've worked hard on that from a -- just from a service level standpoint, strategic higher standpoint, but we also are working just as hard on growing the retail side of the business.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you think the commercial revenues in those California CSK stores, are they getting to that 40%, 45% store revenues?
componenttext: Do you think the commercial revenues in those California CSK stores, are they getting to that 40%, 45% store revenues?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: They're not quite there yet.
componenttext: They're not quite there yet.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mike Baker from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mike Baker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry if this [indiscernible] I dropped off for a minute there, but you're clearly taking market share, is that -- we know it's because of the company specific things that you're doing, but what are you seeing from other competitors? There's been some dis
componenttext: Sorry if this [indiscernible] I dropped off for a minute there, but you're clearly taking market share, is that -- we know it's because of the company specific things that you're doing, but what are you seeing from other competitors? There's been some disruption in -- from some of those guys. Are you seeing certain competitors receive more share than they have historically?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a store-by-store find out there every day. This morning as we're releasing our results, our store managers and installer service specialists are out there trying to take business, and our competitors are doing the exact same thing. So we have a lot o
componenttext: It's a store-by-store find out there every day. This morning as we're releasing our results, our store managers and installer service specialists are out there trying to take business, and our competitors are doing the exact same thing. So we have a lot of strong competitors that do a nice job. And really, nothing that we've seen has changed much. We've always had strong competitors, and they've always done a pretty nice job, some better than others. But we really haven't seen a change in the tack that our competitors have taken in driving their companies other than the things that our publicly-traded competitors talk about in trying to improve their distribution systems to be more comparable to maybe ours and Genuine Parts and just trying to solve the availability equation, which is a challenge without the robust distribution network that companies like ours have.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: But so you're clearly taking more market share than you have in the past, but I guess in your view, that's more a function of what you guys are doing differently than you have in the past. I think you've always been market share gainers, but it seems like
componenttext: But so you're clearly taking more market share than you have in the past, but I guess in your view, that's more a function of what you guys are doing differently than you have in the past. I think you've always been market share gainers, but it seems like it's accelerating. You think that's more a result of what you guys are doing rather than what competitors are doing or not doing?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would attribute our market share gains to just the success of our teams on The Street and the work they're putting in to maintaining customer and growing customer relationships on the do-it-for-me side, the improvements that we've made on our DIY b
componenttext: Yes, I would attribute our market share gains to just the success of our teams on The Street and the work they're putting in to maintaining customer and growing customer relationships on the do-it-for-me side, the improvements that we've made on our DIY business the last few years. And really, just the day-in/day-out blocking and tackling on a store by store basis and making sure that the service levels we provide are higher than our competitors. And then at the same time, leveraging our strong distribution network to make sure we have the best availability in the industry. And a lot of that comes from just brute strength and distribution capacity, but a lot of that also comes from the science that we put into making sure we have the right products in the right locations and that we do a better job than our competitors and making sure that the parts that we anticipate our customers are going to walk into our stores needing based on the vehicle population in each market are the parts that we have in stock in the stores and our hubs and in our distribution centers.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. If I could ask one more real quick. How do you think about -- and I think this was asked in calls periodically, but any updated thoughts on M&A in this space? Anyone out there in terms of acquisitions, either big or small, that you g
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. If I could ask one more real quick. How do you think about -- and I think this was asked in calls periodically, but any updated thoughts on M&A in this space? Anyone out there in terms of acquisitions, either big or small, that you guys will consider?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, there's a lot of things companies out there that are not publicly traded that are private and do pretty well. There would be potential acquisition targets for us. We continue to explore that as we being geographically and we even consider co
componenttext: Well, I mean, there's a lot of things companies out there that are not publicly traded that are private and do pretty well. There would be potential acquisition targets for us. We continue to explore that as we being geographically and we even consider companies sometimes in existing markets. And we do some kind of minor acquisitions ongoing on single stores and things like that, but I don't see anything big on the horizon right now that I could speak of obviously.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Simeon Gutman from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from Simeon Gutman from Morgan Stanley.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, on DIY, a lot of attention on it so far. Do you think there's a pickup in the secular demand? Or is this all the gains or a lot of the gains you're seeing is mostly market share gains?
componenttext: Greg, on DIY, a lot of attention on it so far. Do you think there's a pickup in the secular demand? Or is this all the gains or a lot of the gains you're seeing is mostly market share gains?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that there's -- I think it's both. I think that we're gaining market share. And I think the DIY business has been pretty good with the economy improving some and gas prices being down, more money in people's pocket, unemployment a little better, m
componenttext: I think that there's -- I think it's both. I think that we're gaining market share. And I think the DIY business has been pretty good with the economy improving some and gas prices being down, more money in people's pocket, unemployment a little better, miles driven up. I think that it's both a secular demand increase, and I think that we're gaining market share.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the balance that we've long talked about where you were primarily a commercial DIFM house and going too far into the DIY side, there's a fine line that you don't want to cross, now you're there. I think -- for this there's probably some acceptance amo
componenttext: And the balance that we've long talked about where you were primarily a commercial DIFM house and going too far into the DIY side, there's a fine line that you don't want to cross, now you're there. I think -- for this there's probably some acceptance among the garages that you could get bigger in that space. Is that -- is there's some point you've passed where now you've put the pedal to the metal a little bit harder? Or are there still some natural resistant points that there's still some product area, et cetera, that you won't go towards?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would say, Simeon, is that we try to do the best we can on both sides of the business, and we treat them somewhat separately from a -- the management standpoint from the perspective that our promotions are different. Sometimes the product dec
componenttext: Well, what I would say, Simeon, is that we try to do the best we can on both sides of the business, and we treat them somewhat separately from a -- the management standpoint from the perspective that our promotions are different. Sometimes the product decisions we make, we have to consider both sides. The -- we don't talk to our do-it-for-me customers a lot about our DIY business. And most of the time, our do-it-for-me customers are not really walking into our stores. We're delivering the parts to them and they're dealing with an installer service specialist who focus solely on that business relationship with them, and then also our territory sales managers and regional field sales managers, store managers, and so forth. So I think we have a lot of business to gain on both sides, and we're less restrictive in the aggressive position that we take on the DIY side now than we ever have been simply because I think that most shops now realize that customers are going to buy parts from someone if they want to work on their own car. They're either going to buy them from one of our competitors or us or maybe even in the -- on the Internet, and that we're going to be completely supportive of them in driving successful businesses for them and making parts available for them. And that there's just a lot of business that they've got out there to take, and to the extent that they provide a service level that's satisfying to their customers and on our customers, in effect, they'll be successful. I think that most of them are less concerned now than ever about the fact that people can buy parts and do their own work if they want to, but they can drive a great business by providing these service levels that are necessary to be successful in the service business today.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And might brief follow-up for Tom on gross margin. You mentioned ex LIFO up almost 80 bps. You said it wasn't up as much as you thought. Was that because of LIFO? Or even on the 80 basis points, you expect it could do better? And I'm asking because the ba
componenttext: And might brief follow-up for Tom on gross margin. You mentioned ex LIFO up almost 80 bps. You said it wasn't up as much as you thought. Was that because of LIFO? Or even on the 80 basis points, you expect it could do better? And I'm asking because the back half guidance, I think implies around 50 bps. And I'd say 80 bps on a FIFO basis is still quite solid, so just trying to think -- how to think about gross margin going forward.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The answer to the question is yes. The LIFO headwind higher than we expected drove the slightly below percentage. Maybe we thought we'd be 52.2%, 52.1%, but we've been pretty consistent in our discussion that we'd be in the 51.8% to 52.2% range basically
componenttext: The answer to the question is yes. The LIFO headwind higher than we expected drove the slightly below percentage. Maybe we thought we'd be 52.2%, 52.1%, but we've been pretty consistent in our discussion that we'd be in the 51.8% to 52.2% range basically quarter-after-quarter, and we've accomplished that. But the additional $5 million headwind over last year was more than we expected.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Lasser from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Lasser from UBS.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's on the performance for over the last few quarters, there's been a clear step up in the same-store sales. And while you've provided some quantitative or qualitative information about various performance within your sectors, could you give us a little
componenttext: It's on the performance for over the last few quarters, there's been a clear step up in the same-store sales. And while you've provided some quantitative or qualitative information about various performance within your sectors, could you give us a little greater sense of has that step up been driven more so by the DIY side of the business? Or has it been driven more so by the DIFM side of the business? Or has both sides of the business stepped up equally?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm looking at a sheet here. I can tell you that for instance, back in 2013, our professional business was growing pretty significantly faster than most of the quarters than our DIY business. For the last 6 quarters or so, they've been much more com
componenttext: Well, I'm looking at a sheet here. I can tell you that for instance, back in 2013, our professional business was growing pretty significantly faster than most of the quarters than our DIY business. For the last 6 quarters or so, they've been much more comparable. And I would've attribute part of that to just the effect the economy tends to have on the DIY business greater than the do-it-for-me business. But just because of the economic condition of what drives someone to maybe work on their own car versus take their car into a shop. So yes, I would say that here recently with the economy doing a little better, unemployment better that the DIY business has improved and the commercial businesses has remained good, but the spread between the performance of the DIY and do-it-for-me has closed a little bit over the last couple of years.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And, Greg, that's a fair point that the economy is probably helped, but if we also look at the spread between your performance and your competitor's performance just on a same-store sales basis, the spread has widened a bit in recent period. So there's --
componenttext: And, Greg, that's a fair point that the economy is probably helped, but if we also look at the spread between your performance and your competitor's performance just on a same-store sales basis, the spread has widened a bit in recent period. So there's -- it would suggest that there's probably also something that O'Reilly is doing that enabling it to gain share. And just observationally, it's occurred at the same time that -- following the rollout of your loyalty program. You've invested a little bit more labor in the stores. So is it -- can you tie those 2 factors or others to the performance of your DIY business?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think those are factors, Michael. No question about it. I mean we work hard here. And we try very hard and our teams on The Street work every single day to show our customers that we want them to walk into our stores on the DIY side. We proved our profe
componenttext: I think those are factors, Michael. No question about it. I mean we work hard here. And we try very hard and our teams on The Street work every single day to show our customers that we want them to walk into our stores on the DIY side. We proved our professional customers every day that we want to earn their business, and that they're going to be best served to buy parts from us and partner with us. So yes, I think that it's hard for me to know exactly what all our competitors' initiatives are. I know what they say publicly and what we see on The Street, but we generally speaking, try to stay focused on what we're doing and what we can do better and where our opportunities are because we have opportunities to improve. And we focus on doing the things that we can do to improve our business. And then frankly, don't spend a whole lot of time analyzing what our competitors are doing unless there's some significant change that we need to react to, which is really relatively rare occurrence.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then my last question is on capital. That's helpful, Greg. My last question is on capital allocation. Your stock and the valuation of your stock is above where it's been historically. So how does that influence both the deployment of excess cash
componenttext: Sure. And then my last question is on capital. That's helpful, Greg. My last question is on capital allocation. Your stock and the valuation of your stock is above where it's been historically. So how does that influence both the deployment of excess cash back to shareholders through share repurchases? And the potential that you use as currency to execute your M&A strategy?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would tell you Michael is historically, it's always proven best for us to deploy our capital into our business through growing new stores, maintaining our existing store base and acquiring other chains of stores. When we look at our M&A strat
componenttext: Well, what I would tell you Michael is historically, it's always proven best for us to deploy our capital into our business through growing new stores, maintaining our existing store base and acquiring other chains of stores. When we look at our M&A strategy, there are players out there that we're interested in, but we're an opportunistic buyer. And our success in buying and assimilating change has a lot to do with buying the right chain at the right price, so that's why we're opportunistic. So we'll continue to look for those as our #1 deployment of capital. When we look at buying stock back, we look at what we think the long-term discounted cash flow value is instead of targets that way.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Sponheimer from Gabelli.
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Sponheimer from Gabelli.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just thinking about how the quarter progressed, can you talk about what, if any, impact you saw from flooding in Texas, ag markets or any impact from oil and some of your energy-related markets?
componenttext: Just thinking about how the quarter progressed, can you talk about what, if any, impact you saw from flooding in Texas, ag markets or any impact from oil and some of your energy-related markets?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's hard to measure exactly what impacts businesses. I know you know, but generally speaking, the bid range we had out in Texas aren't initially good for business. When things kind of shut down, and people can't drive because of water over the roads and
componenttext: It's hard to measure exactly what impacts businesses. I know you know, but generally speaking, the bid range we had out in Texas aren't initially good for business. When things kind of shut down, and people can't drive because of water over the roads and stuff like that, that obviously isn't good for us. But in the long run, we feel like it levels back up because of the damage created. Generally, we kind of the way the quarter went was April was really good. May was not as good and June was really good. And I attribute May's softness or slightly softer results to the heavy rains that we had and just the fact that we've had cooler temperatures, rain, not as good as HVAC business and stuff like that.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. Also just thinking about pricing and any pressures ex oil, how are you guys thinking about inflation versus deflation in some of your nonpetroleum-related products at this point?
componenttext: Okay, got it. Also just thinking about pricing and any pressures ex oil, how are you guys thinking about inflation versus deflation in some of your nonpetroleum-related products at this point?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't -- I don't expect deflation. Well, we've not seen a lot of inflation for some time. I -- we expect over at some point that we might start seeing some inflation and some of the hard parts products, but that's just not been the case for som
componenttext: Well, we haven't -- I don't expect deflation. Well, we've not seen a lot of inflation for some time. I -- we expect over at some point that we might start seeing some inflation and some of the hard parts products, but that's just not been the case for some time. From a pricing standpoint, it's always competitive out there, and we always have competitors who, on the do-it-for-me side more than the DIY side, tend to try and take business with a lower price for short periods of time to try and change buying habits and stuff like that. But that's nothing new, that's been the case forever. So really, nothing's changed on the pricing front. It's always competitive. And as I said earlier, we have a lot of really strong and really good competitors who do a lot of different things to try and gain market share. And some, of course, use prices and means to try and develop a relationship with the do-it-for-me customer, but that's nothing new. I've been doing this 31 years, and that happened the first day I was working at O'Reilly stores, so that's nothing new.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Anything on the way as far as wage inflation that could be impactful for you from a cost perspective.
componenttext: Great. Anything on the way as far as wage inflation that could be impactful for you from a cost perspective.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know about the impact effect, but, of course, we stay in tune with all the discussion about minimum wage changes and stuff like that. And as those things, if they come to fruition, we'll be measuring and planning and including those in our f
componenttext: Well, I don't know about the impact effect, but, of course, we stay in tune with all the discussion about minimum wage changes and stuff like that. And as those things, if they come to fruition, we'll be measuring and planning and including those in our forecast for results.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we have reached our allotted time for questions, and I will now turn the call over to Greg Henslee for closing remarks.
componenttext: And we have reached our allotted time for questions, and I will now turn the call over to Greg Henslee for closing remarks.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, John. We would like to conclude our call today by again thanking Team O'Reilly for another quarter of record-breaking results. We remain very confident in the continued strength of our long-term drivers for demand in the automotive afterm
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, John. We would like to conclude our call today by again thanking Team O'Reilly for another quarter of record-breaking results. We remain very confident in the continued strength of our long-term drivers for demand in the automotive aftermarket and in our team's ability to consistently provide unsurpassed levels of service to our customers. We remain absolutely focused on extending our long history of profitable growth as we build on our very strong performance for the first half of the year. I would like to thank everyone for joining our call today, and we look forward to reporting our 2015 third quarter results in October. Thank you.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This concludes today's conference. Thank you for participating. You may now disconnect.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the O'Reilly Automotive, Inc. Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. My name is Ethan, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.I will now turn the call
componenttext:
Welcome to the O'Reilly Automotive, Inc. Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. My name is Ethan, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Tom McFall. Mr. McFall, you may begin.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ethan. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. During today's conference call, we'll discuss our third quarter 2015 results and our outlook for the remainder of 2015. After our prepared comments, we'll host a question-and-answer p
componenttext:
Thank you, Ethan. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. During today's conference call, we'll discuss our third quarter 2015 results and our outlook for the remainder of 2015. After our prepared comments, we'll host a question-and-answer period. Before we begin this morning, I'd like to remain everyone that our comments today contain certain forward-looking statements that we intend to be covered by and claim the protection under the Safe Harbor Provisions for forward-looking statements contained in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. You can identify these statements by forward-looking statements such as estimate, may, could, will, believe, expect, would, consider, should, anticipate, project, plan, intend or similar words. The company's actual results could differ materially from any forward-looking statements due to several important factors described in  the company's latest annual report on Form 10-K ended December 31, 2014, and other recent SEC filings. The company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements made during this call.
At this time, I'd like to introduce Greg Henslee.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the O'Reilly Auto Parts Third Quarter Conference Call. participating on the call with me this morning is, of course, Tom McFall, our Chief Financial Officer; and Jeff Shaw, our Executive Vice President o
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the O'Reilly Auto Parts Third Quarter Conference Call. participating on the call with me this morning is, of course, Tom McFall, our Chief Financial Officer; and Jeff Shaw, our Executive Vice President of Store Operations and Sales; David O'Reilly, our Executive Chairman; and Greg Johnson, our Executive Vice President of Supply Chain, are also present.
It's my pleasure to again begin our quarterly call by congratulating Team O'Reilly on another record-breaking quarter, and an extremely successful first three quarters of 2015.
Our team of over 72,000 dedicated team members continues to win business and take market share by providing consistently excellent customer service, evidenced by our third quarter 7.9% comparable store sales increase. In all three quarters of 2015, we've generated comparable store sales growth in excess of 7%, and these results were on top of difficult comparisons as our team has generated a remarkable 8 straight quarters of comparable store sales growth in excess of 5%. This consistently robust top line performance is the direct result of our team's dedication to living the O'Reilly culture of providing incredible levels of service to each of our valued customers. And I want to thank each of our team members for their continued contributions to our company's long-term success.
For the third quarter, we robustly grew our total sales by 10.8%, and with our focus on growing sales profitably and controlling our expenses, we generated our first-ever 20% operating profit quarter. During the quarter, we resolved a historic tax item, which added $0.11 to our quarterly EPS of $2.64. This resolution, while very positive for the company, is not part of our ongoing business so I think the more appropriate number to focus on is an adjusted third quarter EPS of $2.53, which represents, an increase of 23% over the prior year.
I couldn't be more pleased with the consistent efforts of our team members to provide unsurpassed service levels to our customers, as the third quarter of 2015 represents the 27th consecutive quarter of EPS growth in excess of 15%.
The comparable store sales increased 7.9%, strongly exceeded our comparable store sales guidance of 3% to 5%, and our performance was relatively consistent on a month-to-month basis.
The composition of our comparable store sales growth in the third quarter was also very similar to the first two quarters of the year. Both our professional and DIY sides of the business were strong contributors to our comparable store sales growth with professional being slightly higher.
Increases in our comparable transaction count and ticket average contributed equally to our growth, with a larger contribution from our professional ticket count, although, our DIY ticket count growth continues to be strong. The increase in average ticket continues to be driven by the secular industry driver of parts complexity with little-to-no help from increases in selling price as the inflation remains muted.
Our performance for the third quarter, as we've seen over the past 1.5 years, was driven by key categories, such as breaks, driveline, and ride control. Additionally, as some are heated up in July, we were very pleased with our heat-related category, such as HVAC or control, batteries and rotating electrical. Through July, the latest data available, miles driven were up 3.6% through the year, representing 17 straight months of year-over-year increases.  We feel this increase driven by relatively low gas prices and improving employment has been an important factor in fueling our robust comparable store sales growth.
In our business, the fourth quarter can be highly variable based on weather, especially in the second half as consumers focus on holiday shopping. Therefore, we feel it's appropriate to establish our fourth quarter comparable store sales guidance at a range of 3% to 5%. And reflecting on our strong year-to-date sales results, we're increasing our full year comparable store sales guidance to a range of 6.5% to 7.5%.
Based on the strength of our first three quarters results, we're raising our full year operating margin guidance to a range of 18.3% to 18.7% of sales to the range of 18.6% to 18.9% of sales. This guidance range includes the negative impact of the $19 million litigation charge from the second quarter, which we discussed during last quarter's conference call.
We're establishing our fourth quarter earnings per share guidance at a range of $1.97 to $2.01. And based on strong year-to-date results, we're increasing our full year earnings per share guidance from a range of $8.59 to $8.69 to a range of $8.97 to $9.01.
This full year guidance range includes the negative impact of the second quarter litigation charge as well as the positive impact in the third quarter from the resolution of the historical tax item, I discussed earlier, which on a net basis potentially offset 
Before I finish up my prepared comments, I'd like to again thank our team for our record-breaking third quarter results. We remain very confident in the long-term drivers for demand in our industry. And we believe we're very well-positioned to capitalize on this demand by consistently providing industry-leading service to our customers every day at every store.
Again, congratulations to Team O'Reilly for the very strong year-to-date results and the solid start we have to our fourth quarter through this point in October.
I'll now turn the call over to Jeff Shaw. Jeff?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to begin today by echoing Greg's comments and congratulating Team O'Reilly on another outstanding quarter. I couldn't be more proud of our teams get-it-done attitude that they roll up their sleeves everyd
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to begin today by echoing Greg's comments and congratulating Team O'Reilly on another outstanding quarter. I couldn't be more proud of our teams get-it-done attitude that they roll up their sleeves everyday with the focus of providing top-notch customer service and wining our customers business.
Our industry-leading comparable store sales growth of 7.9% for the quarter and 7.4% for the first three quarters of 2015 is a testament to our team of 72,000-plus team members, who are committed to providing consistently excellent customer service as we worked tirelessly to make sure that we've the and most knowledgeable parts stored in every market we serve.
For the quarter, we grew total revenues 10.8% and total gross margin dollars by 12.5% proving yet again that our ability to provide exceptional service, a wide product offering at comparative prices and superior parts availability allows us to generate sustainable, profitable growth. This growth doesn't have without the dedication of our store, D.C. and office support teams.
For the quarter, SG&A 87 basis points on our strong sales performance and average SG&A per store increased 2.9%. For the year, SG&A per store, excluding the unusual litigation item in the second quarter increased 2.3%. As we discussed on the last few calls, our average per store SG&A spend has been higher than we planned at the beginning of the year, however, we've seen the opportunities add hours to the stores to accelerate our share gain.
Based on our strong year-to-date results, we're very pleased with the direction we've taken, but we continue to closely monitor our sales volumes though we'll make the appropriate adjustments to ensure store payroll levels adds to business.
With our strong sales and profitability results, we've also seen a corresponding increase in variable composition throughout the organization as we reward Team Members at every level --
 
[Audio Gap]
and adjusting our hub, D.C. -- and routes to ensure we have the best availability in each market we serve. The knowledge and dedication of our supply chain team 
[Audio Gap] 
Texas D.C. in the second quarter of 2016. We've had a great year so far and we're well-positioned to continue to provide our customers exceptional service levels and the best parts availability in the industry, so that we finish up the year strong. That said, we can never rest our past successes and we've to go out in our own the business in each and everyday by -- and outsourcing our competitors, and I'm confident in our team's ability to do just that.  Great job Team O'Reilly.
Now I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. I'd also like to thank all of the Team O'Reilly on another outstanding quarter.Now we'll take a closer look at our quarterly results and update our guidance for the remainder of 2015. For the quarter, sales increased $203 million, comprise
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff. I'd also like to thank all of the Team O'Reilly on another outstanding quarter.
Now we'll take a closer look at our quarterly results and update our guidance for the remainder of 2015. For the quarter, sales increased $203 million, comprised of $145 million increase in comp store sales, $58 million increase in non-comp store sales, $2 million increase in non-comp non-store sales and $2 million decrease from closed stores.
Based on our strong year-to-date performance, we're raising our full year total revenue guidance to a range of $7.85 billion to $7.95 billion. For the quarter, gross margin was 52.4% of sales, and improved 78 basis points over the prior year. This was in line with expectations as positive mix from leverage on distribution costs, offset a higher-than-expected LIFO charge of $5 million, which was a 10 basis -- excuse me, which as 10 basis points less than last year.
Based on our year-to-date results, we're -- our full year gross margin guidance from a range of 51.8% to 52.2% of sales to a range of 52.0% to 52.2% of sales.
Our effective tax rate for the third quarter was 33.6% pretax income. During the third quarter of each year, we typically experienced a lower tax rate as we adjust our tax reserves for closed tax period. As Greg mentioned earlier, we had a non-typical tax reserve adjustment this year related to a previous acquisitions. This non-typical adjustment is a non-recurring noncash item, which added $0.11 to our quarterly EPS and lowered our effective tax rate by 2.7% pretax income. Excluding this item, our effective tax rate would have been 36.3%, which is where we thought we would be.  For the fourth quarter, we expect an effective tax rate of approximately 37.3% of pretax income.
Now moving on to free cash flow for the components that drove our results from the quarter and our updated guidance and expectations for the full year of 2015. Free cash flow for the quarter was $254 million. Based on our strong year-to-date performance, we're revising our full year guidance for free cash flow to the range of $800 million to $850 million, reflecting an increase of $75 million on both ends of the range.
Inventory per store at the end of the quarter was 576,000, which is 1.5% decrease from the end of 2014. Our ongoing goal is to ensure we grow per store inventory at a lower rate than the  comparable store sales growth generate, and we definitely accomplish that goal through the first three quarters in 2015.
We continue to make great progress in reducing slow-moving and overstock product, and are replacing it with the additional store level inventory of products that are entering the higher demand cycles. However, part of this decrease is timing related to the very strong sales during the first three quarters of the year, and we continue to expect our per-store inventory to increase a little less than 1% per store for the full year.
Our AP to inventory ratio finished the third quarter at 101%. This is the first time our net inventory investment has been negative. We're excited about the accomplishment, but this ratio was aided by seasonality in our extremely strong sales.  As a result, we expect to finish up 2015 at an AP to inventory ration just under 100%.
Capital expenditures for the first 9 months were $296 million, which is a little less than we plan, but we still expect our 2015 CapEx to be within that range of $400 million to $430 million.
Moving on to debt, we finished the third quarter with an adjusted debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.6x, still well below our targeted ratio of 2x to 2.25x. We continue to believe our stated range is appropriate level for our business. And we'll move into this range when the timing is appropriate.
We continue to execute our share repurchase program and from July 1st through yesterday, we repurchased 1.3 million shares of our stock at an average cost of $239.81 per share for a total investment of $305 million. We continue to view our buyback program as an effective means of returning available cash to shareholders after we take advantage of opportunities to invest in our business at a higher rate of return.  And we'll prudently execute our program with an emphasis on long-term returns for our shareholders.
For the fourth quarter, we're establishing diluted earnings per share guidance of $1.97 to $2.01. Based on our above planned results thus far in 2015, and additional shares as we've purchased since our last call, for the full year, we're raising our guidance to $8.97 to $9.01 per share, representing an increase of $0.35 per share to midpoint from our previously announced guidance.
As a reminder, our diluted earnings per share guidance for both the fourth quarter and full year taking into account, the shares we purchased through yesterday, but did not reflect the impact of any potential future share repurchase.
Finally, I'd like to once again thank the entire O'Reilly team for their continued dedication to the company's success. Congratulations on another outstanding performance in the third quarter.
This concludes our prepared comments. At this time, I'd like to ask, the operator return the line, and we'll be happy to answer your questions.

componenttext: Well, Michael, this is Greg. Well, what I tell you there is just a lot going on the industry, and you guys have seen the M&A activity that's going on as some of the companies that have previously been more retail have come into the wholesale business, we see pressure being put on some of the weaker players in each market, which we provide some opportunity for us. We kind of up our supply chain and the number of times that we touch each store in the last few years and improve some of the retail services that we provide. So we -- and we've proven I think over the last 2 or 3 years or whatever, we have the ability to pick up some market share, and I think that we're going to going to be able to do that. And for that reason, we're pretty robust in a way we deploy staffing in the stores as a means of continuing a trend of gaining market share.

componenttext: My primary question relates to take a trend, and you've spoken I think more eloquently than most about parts complexity, as a driver of the business and something that will contributor to your strength. Can you talk about the degree to which this is building? And if you think about the that we are in and this might be of -- an analyst I guess. What point do you feel, like I guess for prospective, you saw the start to move the ticket -- isn't having a growing impact on ticket as we move forward here?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it has had a growing impact, and I think it will continue to for the foreseeable future. Cars continue to increasing complexity. There's a lot of technology that's been deploying cars that wasn't a few years ago, and I'd expect that continue -- to
componenttext: I think it has had a growing impact, and I think it will continue to for the foreseeable future. Cars continue to increasing complexity. There's a lot of technology that's been deploying cars that wasn't a few years ago, and I'd expect that continue -- to continue to increase. Example would be -- and we were talking about this internally the other day when it comes to vehicle ignitions, for instance, cars just a few years ago, had distributor caps with a -- and each cylinder had a ignition wire, and today most vehicles have a ignition coil on each spark plug. And while the ignition coils are replacing as part of normal vehicle maintenance during a tuneup and the cap and rotor and the ignition wires would have been when those coils fail, they are very expensive. And at higher milages, they fail and -- the trade-off is that we sell a lot fewer units and maybe the frequency of the sale is less. But when we do sell a coil, it's a much more expensive sale. And since there is one on each cylinder, there is several other car. And that kind of thing exists in several -- fuel pumps, used to cars shed in mechanical fuel pumps or a in-line fuel pump going up to the carburetor or throttle body injection, today vehicles have an in-tank fuel pump that acts as not only the fuel pump, but also the fuel gate sending in it. Down in the fuel pumps is a very technical part, they sell for average maybe a couple of hundred dollars a piece, where as the older fuel pumps might sell for $20 to $40 a piece. So good products, maybe don't fail as oftern. They are all mechanical pumps or the pumps. They're more expensive when --

componenttext: What I'd tell you is that we continue to work with each supplier to see where our opportunities are. We're excited that we got a 101 this particular period. We'll have some pressure as we go into the end of the year, just based on the velocity of business. We hadn't posted the extremely strong comps that we have, we wouldn't have that ratio. When we look at long-term, we continue to have some opportunities to extent some of our suppliers, but I think the key for us now is to really focus on what our inventory turns on -- are we've talked about in the prepared remarks to make sure, either we have the right products in the store that are moving to provide their customer service throughout our layers to optimize that, but really to work on where do we have inventory deployed -- we're not giving return, and how do we adjust that. So that's a big driver to our EBITDA-to-inventory ratio.

componenttext: I wanted to, Greg, get your thoughts around whether in the sense that -- there's a lot of discussion around -- How do you think about as you look into '16? How that potentially plays out versus some of the structural positives around gas prices and the aging car fleet? And as you look back one of the past 3 quarters, due you think weather has been, I guess, a plus or minus or neutral?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're not great predictors of the weather. And really looking back 3 years, we really didn't spend much time even talking about this, as we've got bigger it's become a little more of a factor with our geographic expansion and so forth. This fall -- most m
componenttext: We're not great predictors of the weather. And really looking back 3 years, we really didn't spend much time even talking about this, as we've got bigger it's become a little more of a factor with our geographic expansion and so forth. This fall -- most markets have not had really very cold weather yet, and some of -- periods that we compared to you last year, we've cool snaps that might drive short-term demand for batteries or something like that. We not really have that yet in most markets. So that's yet to come. What I would say is that if we have a mild winter, some of the demand that would be created by the a more extreme winter would be for going to be next year if there were parts that were going to fail in the wintertime, or pressure that was put on parts that were -- fail anyway at some point, but didn't have the pressure put on by the cold weather, so that might be kick down the road to maybe the winter of '16 or something like that. So as we've always said, extreme weather is generally good for us. Real cold or real hot causes parts to fail more premature than they would typically, but they're still going to fail. So it's just mid-May push some of the down the road a little bit that we might gain during more extreme weather. I think the -- this year has been pretty normal weather, I think the summer started pretty -- but it turned out being pretty hot in most markets, so we did well in some of the heat-related categories, as I mentioned in our prepared remarks. I think that the gives it average winner, I don't think it was extreme in most markets, and I don't think we benefited as we typically would from the damage that the cars in the extreme cold. And I'd expect in many markets would have some version of a cold winter this year, although, I know that there's could be some effort from this So that would be my comment. I don't think it's a major factor to consider. I think it -- the economic issues that we discussed relative to gas prices, miles driven, the health of the consumer and as pointed rates improving or powerful typically been what the weather would be.

componenttext: So the last 7 quarters or so, you guys have experienced a pretty material ramp up in your retail sales, it seems to coincide with the launch of your loyalty program, but it's not a standalone issue because you've been weekend and night hours, et cetera. So I guess, 2 kind of related questions. Number one, how much of your improvement in the retail sales are from this changes, and then how much do you think is just from improvements in the markets such as the unemployment stuff you've already talked about? Number two, related to that, of the changes that you've made, what you think is had the bigger impact? Is it been the loyalty program, or it been the increase in the store hours?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Scot, those things are hard to know for sure. We know -- as you know that our retail business has grown pretty robustly. And the things you mentioned relative to our efforts to staff that's are on at nights and weekends, make sure that the service l
componenttext: Well, Scot, those things are hard to know for sure. We know -- as you know that our retail business has grown pretty robustly. And the things you mentioned relative to our efforts to staff that's are on at nights and weekends, make sure that the service levels that we provide are extremely high, and we now include in those -- the services we provide somethings that we didn't 3 years ago, relatively to be maybe the occasional batter insulation or wiper blades, occasional lightbulb, pulling check engine, light and troubled codes off cars, stuff like that. And then, of course, the over words program, which we now have over 18 million enrolled customers, and we're averaging 120, 125 new enrollees. So -- all those things are contributors. And then, of course, the improving our big contributors, also just to demand for retail. It's really hard for us to know. I think all those things put together -- got us where we are, I think the awards programs are important. I think the services that we provide, that we didn't provide previously -- providing them now, we partially done little earlier. And the staffing is just something that we -- focused on for a long time and we've just gotten better and better. I think we continue to improve as the time goes along, and we deploy better systems to help us manage the staffing in our stores and make sure the store managers have the information they need to optimize the way they staff stores. But it hard for me to quantify which is the bigger contributor at all. They are all significant contributors.

But again, we don't have any way of knowing while we've gotten anyway, but I continue to believe that's it's going to a positive thing for us, and will continue to be a positive thing for us as customers benefit from the rewards that we offer them and they reward us with the loyalty.

componenttext: I think so. It's hard for us to measure share gains just like it's hard for you all to measure share gains. And really are only means of measuring wholesale share gains, basically as by comparing to the results of our publicly traded competitors, and those that we know in the industry that tell us how our sales are. That seems the only way we've of comparing. And I think the 7.9% comp that we generated in our third quarter speaks for itself relative to cash market share, but that really -- it's a very basic comparison and a very general comment when we say we're gaining market share, and strictly based on our perception of we're performing versus the companies that were publicly and those that we know in the industry.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, the question is obviously, I don't anyone expecting percent comp is the new run rate for you. But at the same time, your pace of share gains has picked up and the things that you described as positive for the industry should be positive for every
componenttext: I guess, the question is obviously, I don't anyone expecting percent comp is the new run rate for you. But at the same time, your pace of share gains has picked up and the things that you described as positive for the industry should be positive for everyone, yet you're relative performance seems to have widened, so just trying to get a sense for what aspects of the performance you think are most sustainable the next couple of years -- segment?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd tell you as we need -- 72,000 and other people here come to work everyday, trying to do the best job we can to provide great levels of service to our customer, and make sure we've the right parts in the right places, and that we know we're talking abo
componenttext: I'd tell you as we need -- 72,000 and other people here come to work everyday, trying to do the best job we can to provide great levels of service to our customer, and make sure we've the right parts in the right places, and that we know we're talking about when it comes to selling parts and fixing cars. And we're going to continue to do what we do, and we're going to continue try and improve the things we do, and improve the way we educate team members, and improve our supply chain, improve the number of times we touch stores, improve the science behind how we deploy inventory. So to the extent that those things are contributing to our market share gains, which I believe they are, I think we'll continue to be a market share gainer. All of this are subject to just drop and the automotive aftermarket is doing, right now, it's pretty robust. So some portion of the 7.9% comp and the 7.4% we've had for the year is a result of the market being pretty robust. And as I mentioned, I think, that in a robust market, we're in a very good portion to take market share because of things I mentioned that I think we do pretty well. And they're very basic things, but there are things we've done for years. And we've just improved on as our company has grown gotten older, and we've gained more expensive, and we put more science behind it and things like that. So I wouldn't expect a change in our ability to grow market share, but the unknown to some degree is just the backdrop of what the macroeconomic environment provides.

componenttextpreview: I had a question regarding the fourth quarter guidance. And the first three quarters of the year, the actual earnings exceeded the high end of guidance by an average of $0.19 a share. Is there anything different about the upcoming fourth quarter that woul
componenttext: I had a question regarding the fourth quarter guidance. And the first three quarters of the year, the actual earnings exceeded the high end of guidance by an average of $0.19 a share. Is there anything different about the upcoming fourth quarter that would make the comparisons more difficult?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I'd tell you, Dan, is my -- in my history with O'Reilly, which is 31 years, I can tell you fourth quarter is the most variable and reducing that can happen to weather intercept to some markets and doesn't in some markets, and that can be a sign
componenttext: Well, what I'd tell you, Dan, is my -- in my history with O'Reilly, which is 31 years, I can tell you fourth quarter is the most variable and reducing that can happen to weather intercept to some markets and doesn't in some markets, and that can be a significant driver of early demand. And then also the holiday shopping season is always a unknown and effective -- business is always a little bit of unknown. So we're always a -- because of our history and our experience in all the fourth quarters that we've lived through, we know that fourth quarter is the most variable. And for that reason, we're -- we generally are pretty conservative, but we're even put more emphasis on our conservatism going into the fourth quarter, as a result of the knowledge we have of the potential variability coming into the holiday season.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Second question, could you discuss O'Reilly's success with the IP acquisition, knowing that those stories had a combination of parts and a service business? And would in mind, is there any opportunity for O'Reilly to participate in the consideration of th
componenttext: Second question, could you discuss O'Reilly's success with the IP acquisition, knowing that those stories had a combination of parts and a service business? And would in mind, is there any opportunity for O'Reilly to participate in the consideration of the industry with the bridge -- merger?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: What I'd tell you is that when we IP, we were pretty skeptical and concerned of having stores with shops that joined, and we kind of worked out how we would do that, and to this point, we've been pleased with our results. If certainly, a challenge because
componenttext: What I'd tell you is that when we IP, we were pretty skeptical and concerned of having stores with shops that joined, and we kind of worked out how we would do that, and to this point, we've been pleased with our results. If certainly, a challenge because our competitors use the fact that we're attached to a shop as it means to imply that there's some partnership that might be unfair to the other commercial customers that we provide parts to, which is not the case. And we make it very transparent and clear that's not the case. But the IP in -- beyond, they've been great partners of ours, and I think both businesses have done well, and we were recently there. I can tell you that our business continues to grow robustly in those stores small base, but if you look to the percentages, you'd be impressed if I told you what it was, which I'm not going to. Tom, I think it's a lot different situation because size for what one thing, but then also the amount of square feet, but what I would say is that when given the opportunity look at that we would assess that in due course just we would in the other -- any other opportunities and decide whether it make sense for us, and what parts of it worked and what parts of it didn't and all those things. But I can tell you, we probably wouldn't be scared of the fact that there is a shop attached. But that's what I'd tell you about -- Bridgestone still has a tender offer out there to close -- And as far as we've heard, we don't know what that will do, they may run the shops, they may not run the shops, so that might be a question better directed to those folks.

componenttext: What we would tell you is -- if we have low -- depends on the mix of products we sell. When we look at the gross margin, our distribution is pretty highly variable, but there will pressure on those fixed cost. When we look at this store cost, it's a difficult question to answer. When we look at what our SG&A was per store with high sales volumes, we're staffed up to meet that. We're probably running overtime because the amount of business we have, we have a higher achievement of variable compensation, we're running a lot more trucks, bringing a lot more fuel. Though all of those costs are very variable. But obviously, this some portion of and there's occupancy cost that are fixed and we're levering. So at a lower comp, we're not going to -- all other things equal, we're not going to put up the operating profit we did this quarter. But we're going make adjustments to fine tune the variable part of our business to match what the business is that's out there.
