componenttextpreview: Well, we continue to look at where our opportunities are to direct our own brands, and that's a margin opportunity for us. We continue to look at how we distribute parts. We continue to look at where opportunities are to leverage our size and buy better,
componenttext: Well, we continue to look at where our opportunities are to direct our own brands, and that's a margin opportunity for us. We continue to look at how we distribute parts. We continue to look at where opportunities are to leverage our size and buy better, sometimes to buy direct. So those all play into it.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Something I would add to that, Chris, is that for most part, the vendors of aftermarket parts, they -- many of them can't supply all of us. So they supply some of us. So many of them make choices as to who they're going to do business with. And I think th
componenttext: Something I would add to that, Chris, is that for most part, the vendors of aftermarket parts, they -- many of them can't supply all of us. So they supply some of us. So many of them make choices as to who they're going to do business with. And I think they're trying to pick companies that they feel like will do a good job distributing their products and representing their products. And I think to some degree, we've benefited from being recognized as a pretty high quality partner when it comes to partnering with a supplier. And for that reason, we've been afforded some gross margin opportunities that maybe we weren't as a smaller company and we are today. And that I think our merchandise cost is a pretty good contributor to our gross margin results.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Scot Ciccarelli from RBC Capital.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Scot Ciccarelli from RBC Capital.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the last 7 quarters or so, you guys have experienced a pretty material ramp up in your retail sales. It seems to coincide with the launch of your loyalty program, but it's not a standalone issue because you've been adding weekend and night hours, et ce
componenttext: So the last 7 quarters or so, you guys have experienced a pretty material ramp up in your retail sales. It seems to coincide with the launch of your loyalty program, but it's not a standalone issue because you've been adding weekend and night hours, et cetera. So I guess, 2 kind of related questions. Number one, how much of your improvement in the retail sales are from these changes, and then how much do you think is just from improvements in the market such as the unemployment stuff you've already talked about? Number two, related to that, of the changes that you've made, what do you think has had the bigger impact? Has it been the loyalty program, or has it been the increase in store hours?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, Scot, those things are hard to know for sure. We know the -- as you know that our regional business has grown pretty robustly. And the things you mentioned relative to our efforts to staff better  on nights and weekends make sure that the servi
componenttext: Yes. Well, Scot, those things are hard to know for sure. We know the -- as you know that our regional business has grown pretty robustly. And the things you mentioned relative to our efforts to staff better  on nights and weekends make sure that the service levels that we provide are extremely high, and that we now include in those services we provide some things that we didn't 3 years ago, relative to maybe the occasional battery installation or wiper blades, and the occasional light bulb, pulling check engine light and trouble codes off cars, stuff like that. And then, of course, the O'Rewards program, which we now have over 18 million enrolled customers, and we're averaging 120, 125 a week new enrollees. So all those things are contributors. And then, of course, the economy improving, miles driven  improving our big contributors also to just the demand for parts retail. It's really hard for us to know. I think all those things put together have got us where we are. I think the O'Rewards programs are important. I think the services that we provide that we didn't provide previously, it's -- I'm glad we're providing them now. We probably should have done them a little earlier. And the staffing is just something that we've focused on for a long time and we've just gotten better and better at it. I think we'll continue to improve that as the time goes along, and we deploy better systems to help us manage the staffing in our stores and make the -- make sure the store managers have the information they need to optimize the way they staff stores. But it's hard for me to quantify which is the bigger contributor. They're all significant contributors.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me rephrase part of the question then. So when you look at specifically the loyalty program, how much of the -- your improvement or -- how much incremental sales, I guess, do you think that loyalty program has been able to drive? I mean, if you'
componenttext: Okay. Let me rephrase part of the question then. So when you look at specifically the loyalty program, how much of the -- your improvement or -- how much incremental sales, I guess, do you think that loyalty program has been able to drive? I mean, if you're going a 100 -- as of August, at least, you're doing 155,000 transactions per day on the loyalty program, that's a really sizable impact on the business I would think, but I don't know what part is incremental and what part is just that these guys are just kind of take advantage of the program?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I don't have the numbers with me, but I'll tell you if we looked at it that way, and I have looked at it that way, it's pretty shocking the number of transactions and the dollar contribution from our loyalty program. The thing that's impossible
componenttext: Yes. Well, I don't have the numbers with me, but I'll tell you if we looked at it that way, and I have looked at it that way, it's pretty shocking the number of transactions and the dollar contribution from our loyalty program. The thing that's impossible to know is how much of that business were we getting prior to that loyalty program. And they're customers that were coming to us previously and we signed them up on a loyalty card, and they continue to do business with them. We hope they're more loyal maybe than they were before, but maybe they were -- we were the only store they came to previously. So we really don't have a good way of knowing, although, as I said a moment ago, if you look just at the transactions and the dollar contribution from the people using our loyalty program, it's material. But again, we don't have any way of knowing what we would have gotten anyway, but I continue to believe that it's been a positive thing for us and will continue to be a positive thing for us as customers benefit from the rewards that we afford them and they reward us with their loyalty.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Daniel Hofkin from William Blair & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Daniel Hofkin from William Blair & Company.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a little more color on this whole general topic of comps. If I understood you correctly, it sounded like you were describing market share gains in both segments. You've talked in recent quarters about DIY showing maybe greater share gains for you. Gi
componenttext: Just a little more color on this whole general topic of comps. If I understood you correctly, it sounded like you were describing market share gains in both segments. You've talked in recent quarters about DIY showing maybe greater share gains for you. Given some of the changes you've made the last couple of years. But it sounded like in addition to that, that commercial you felt like either because of some of the squeeze out of smaller players maybe that's picked up in terms of share gains for you as well. Is that a fair characterization?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think so. It's hard for us to measure share gains just like it's hard for you all to measure share gains. And really our only means of measuring wholesale share gains, basically, is by comparing to the results of our publicly traded competitors and thos
componenttext: I think so. It's hard for us to measure share gains just like it's hard for you all to measure share gains. And really our only means of measuring wholesale share gains, basically, is by comparing to the results of our publicly traded competitors and those that we know in the industry that tell us how their sales are. That's really the only way we have of comparing. And I think the 7.9% comp that we generated in the third quarter kind of speaks for itself relative to market share, but really it's a very basic comparison and a very general comment when we say we're gaining market share and it's strictly based on our perception of how we're performing versus the companies that report publicly and those that we know in the industry.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I guess, the question is obviously, I don't think anyone's expecting that  an 8% comp is the new run rate for you. But at the same time, your pace of share gains has picked up and the things that you described as positive for the industry sho
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I guess, the question is obviously, I don't think anyone's expecting that  an 8% comp is the new run rate for you. But at the same time, your pace of share gains has picked up and the things that you described as positive for the industry should be positive for everyone, yet your relative performance seems to have widened. So just trying to get a sense for what aspects of the performance do you think are most sustainable the next couple of years in either segment?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Daniel, what I'd tell you is we -- me and 72,000 other people here come to work everyday, trying to do the best job we can to provide great levels of service to our customer, and make sure we have the right parts in the right places, and that we kno
componenttext: Well, Daniel, what I'd tell you is we -- me and 72,000 other people here come to work everyday, trying to do the best job we can to provide great levels of service to our customer, and make sure we have the right parts in the right places, and that we know what we're talking about when it comes to selling parts and fixing cars. And we're going to continue to do what we do and we're going to continue try and improve the things we do and improve the way we educate team members and improve our supply chain, improve the number of times we touch storesdoors, improve the science behind how we deploy inventory. So to the extent that those things are contributing to our market share gains, which I believe they are, I think we'll continue to be a market share gainer. Yet, all of us are subject to just the macro backdrop and the business that the automotive aftermarket is doing, and right now, it's pretty robust. So some portion of the 7.9% comp and the 7.4% comp we've had for the year is a result of the market being pretty robust. And as I mentioned, I think, that in a robust market, we're in a very good position to take market share because of the things I mentioned that I think we do pretty well. And they're very basic things, but they're things we've done for years and we've just improved on as our company has grown and gotten older and we've all gained more experience and we put more science behind it and things like that. So I wouldn't expect a change in our ability to grow market share, but the unknown to some degree is just the backdrop of what the macroeconomic environment provides.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. Last, just very quick housekeeping question, just on the whole -- you talked about the $0.11 benefit this quarter from the tax favorability. If I recall correctly, in the second quarter, you had the litigation on the unfavorable side,
componenttext: That's very helpful. Last, just very quick housekeeping question, just on the whole -- you talked about the $0.11 benefit this quarter from the tax favorability. If I recall correctly, in the second quarter, you had the litigation on the unfavorable side, don't those kind of washout overall, so that the base comparison -- if we're thinking about projecting into  next year and we look at first 9-months as a whole, do you still get to a relatively clean base level of earnings, am I correct about that?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Those 2 are pretty offsetting. One's pretax, one's post-tax. So they're -- they basically create a neutral.
componenttext: Yes. Those 2 are pretty offsetting. One's pretax, one's post-tax. So they're -- they basically create a neutral.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Dan Wewer from Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Dan Wewer from Raymond James.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had a question regarding the fourth quarter guidance. In the first 3 quarters of the year, the actual earnings exceeded the high end of guidance by an average of $0.19 a share. Is there anything different about the upcoming fourth quarter that would mak
componenttext: I had a question regarding the fourth quarter guidance. In the first 3 quarters of the year, the actual earnings exceeded the high end of guidance by an average of $0.19 a share. Is there anything different about the upcoming fourth quarter that would make the comparisons more difficult?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I'd tell you, Dan, is that my -- in my history with O'Reilly, which is 31 years, I can tell you the fourth quarter is the most variable. There is just things that can happen related to weather interception in some markets and doesn't in some ma
componenttext: Well, what I'd tell you, Dan, is that my -- in my history with O'Reilly, which is 31 years, I can tell you the fourth quarter is the most variable. There is just things that can happen related to weather interception in some markets and doesn't in some markets, and that can be a significant driver of early demand. And then also the holiday shopping season is always a unknown and the effect of that on our business is always a little bit of an unknown. So we're always -- because of our history and our experience in all the fourth quarters that we've lived through, we know that fourth quarter is the most variable. And for that reason, we're -- we generally are pretty conservative, but -- and we even put more emphasis on our conservatism going into the fourth quarter as a result of the knowledge we have of the potential variability coming into the holiday season.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question, can you discuss O'Reilly's success with the IP acquisition, knowing that those stores had a combination of a parts and a service business? And with that in mind, is there any opportunity for O'Reilly to participate in the consolidat
componenttext: Okay. Second question, can you discuss O'Reilly's success with the IP acquisition, knowing that those stores had a combination of a parts and a service business? And with that in mind, is there any opportunity for O'Reilly to participate in the consolidation of the industry with the Bridgestone Pep Boys merger?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, what I would tell you is that when we assessed the IP, we were pretty skeptical and concerned of having stores with shops adjoined, and we kind of worked out how we would do that, and to this point, we've been pleased with our results. It was c
componenttext: Yes. Well, what I would tell you is that when we assessed the IP, we were pretty skeptical and concerned of having stores with shops adjoined, and we kind of worked out how we would do that, and to this point, we've been pleased with our results. It was certainly a challenge because our competitors use the fact that we're attached to a shop as a means to imply that there's some partnerships that might be unfair to the other professional customers that we provide parts to, which is not the case, and we make it very transparent and clear that that's not the case. But VIP, and John Quirk, the owner, they've been great partners of ours, and I think both businesses have done well, and we're reasonably comfortable there. I can tell you that our business continues to grow robustly in those stores. We're coming off from a small base, but if you look to the percentages, boy, it's -- you'd be impressed if I told you what it was, which I'm not going to. But the -- talking about Pep Boys, I think that it's a lot different situation because of the size of it for one thing, but then also the amount of square feet, but what I would say is that if given the opportunity to look at that, we would assess that in due course just like we would any other opportunity and decide whether it made sense for us and what parts of it worked and what parts of it didn't and all those things. But I can tell you, we probably wouldn't be scared of the fact that there's a shop attached. And Tom has a comment also.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: What I would tell, though, Dan, is Bridgestone still has a tender offer out there to close Pep Boys. And as far as we've heard, we don't know what they're going to do with -- they may run the shops, they may not run the shops, so that might be a question
componenttext: What I would tell, though, Dan, is Bridgestone still has a tender offer out there to close Pep Boys. And as far as we've heard, we don't know what they're going to do with -- they may run the shops, they may not run the shops, so that might be a question better directed to those folks.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Tony Cristello from BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Tony Cristello from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, I wanted to talk a little bit about O'Reilly in the business model and the margin, and how that looks in a normalized comp assuming that 7.9% is not normalized. 20% EBIT margin is really solid, and I'm just wondering the variability of cost and l
componenttext: I guess, I wanted to talk a little bit about O'Reilly in the business model and the margin, and how that looks in a normalized comp assuming that 7.9% is not normalized. 20% EBIT margin is really solid, and I'm just wondering the variability of cost and labor and some of the other things, what does margin look like in a 3% to 5% comp versus a 7.9%  comp?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, do you want to take that?
componenttext: Tom, do you want to take that?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what we would tell you is that if we have low -- it depends on the mix of products we sell when we look at the gross margin. Our distribution is pretty highly variable, but there will be pressure on those fixed costs. When we look at the store costs
componenttext: Well, what we would tell you is that if we have low -- it depends on the mix of products we sell when we look at the gross margin. Our distribution is pretty highly variable, but there will be pressure on those fixed costs. When we look at the store costs, it's a difficult question to answer. When we look at what our SG&A was per store with high sales volumes, we're staffed up to meet that. We're probably running overtime because of the amount of business we have. We have a higher achievement of variable compensation and we're running a lot more trucks, burning a lot more fuel, so all of those costs are very variable. But obviously, there's some portion of payroll and there's occupancy costs that are fixed that we're levering. So at a lower comp, we're not going to -- all other things equal, we're not going to put up the operating profit we did this quarter. But we're going make adjustments to fine tune the variable part of our business to match what the business is that's out there.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, is it a benefit with the initiatives you've had for the retail side of the business, which I understand it to be a higher margin-type business if there's a stickiness there or what you've done from an initiative standpoint holds. Do you
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, is it a benefit with the initiatives you've had for the retail side of the business, which I understand it to be a higher margin-type business if there's a stickiness there or what you've done from an initiative standpoint holds. Do you think that, that changes the margin profile for the longer term? Or do you think that, all else being equal, you will just ebb and flow with what the comp does?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, additional retail contribution is certainly favorable. It's -- like you said, it's higher gross margin, and they bring the money with them. So it's a -- and you don't have to deliver the parts, so it's a great thing. So yes, to the extent there are
componenttext: Well, additional retail contribution is certainly favorable. It's -- like you said, it's higher gross margin, and they bring the money with them. So it's a -- and you don't have to deliver the parts, so it's a great thing. So yes, to the extent there are rental business growth that we were able to hold on to that and may continue to grow, which I think we will, that's a positive thing and it's a contributor to our margin and will be helpful at a lower comp rate in generating flow through to operating margin.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just ask a follow-up on the hours. Is it primarily geared toward the commercial side of the business? Or are the hours intuitively driven towards extending reachable retail side?
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just ask a follow-up on the hours. Is it primarily geared toward the commercial side of the business? Or are the hours intuitively driven towards extending reachable retail side?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, they send it out. We open early, of course, for the wholesale customers, because many of them get their shops up and running pretty early and we want to be sure that parts that they may have ordered the day before or whatever gets to their shop first
componenttext: Yes, they send it out. We open early, of course, for the wholesale customers, because many of them get their shops up and running pretty early and we want to be sure that parts that they may have ordered the day before or whatever gets to their shop first thing. But we -- later in the day, DIY-ers, many of them work for a living, obviously, and they are -- the reason we keep our stores open late and staff our stores right on nights and weekends is, generally speaking, to serve the DIY customers.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we have reached our allotted time for questions. I will now turn the call back over to Greg Henslee.
componenttext: And we have reached our allotted time for questions. I will now turn the call back over to Greg Henslee.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Ethan. We'd like to conclude our call today by thanking the entire O'Reilly Team for the outstanding year-to-date results. We're extremely proud of our record-breaking third quarter results and extremely confident in our ability to contin
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, Ethan. We'd like to conclude our call today by thanking the entire O'Reilly Team for the outstanding year-to-date results. We're extremely proud of our record-breaking third quarter results and extremely confident in our ability to continue to aggressively and profitably gain market share and are focused on continuing our momentum into the fourth quarter. I'd like to thank everyone for joining our call today, and we look forward to reporting our 2015 fourth quarter and full year results in February of next year. Thank you.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This concludes today's conference. Thank you for participating. You may now disconnect.
